png-alpha.title: PNG alpha transparency
png-alpha.notes: IE6 does support full transparency in 8-bit PNGs, which can sometimes be an alternative to 24-bit PNGs.

apng.title: Animated PNG (APNG)
apng.description: Like animated GIFs, but allowing 24-bit colors and alpha transparency

links.title: Microsoft Edge feature request on UserVoice

apng.notes: Where support for APNG is missing, only the first frame is displayed

video.title: Video element
video.description: Method of playing videos on webpages (without requiring a plug-in).

links.title: Video on the Web - includes info on Android support

video.notes: Different browsers have support for different video formats, see sub-features for details.

notes_by_num.1: The Android browser (before 2.3) requires [specific handling](http://www.broken-links.com/2010/07/08/making-html5-video-work-on-android-phones/) to run the video element.

audio.title: Audio element
audio.description: Method of playing sound on webpages (without requiring a plug-in).

links.title: Demos of audio player that uses the audio element

contenteditable.title: contenteditable attribute (basic support)
contenteditable.description: Method of making any HTML element editable.
contenteditable.notes: This support only refers to very basic editing capability, implementations vary significantly on how certain elements can be edited.

dragndrop.title: Drag and Drop
dragndrop.description: Method of easily dragging and dropping elements on a page, requiring minimal JavaScript.

links.title: Microsoft Edge setDragImage feature request on UserVoice

dragndrop.notes:
`dataTransfer.items` only supported by Chrome.

Currently no browser supports the `dropzone` attribute.

Firefox supports any kind of DOM elements for `.setDragImage`. Chrome must have either an `HTMLImageElement` or any kind of DOM elements attached to the DOM and within the viewport of the browser for `.setDragImage`.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support refers to no support for the `dataTransfer.files` or `.types` objects and limited supported formats for `dataTransfer.setData`/`getData`.
notes_by_num.2: Partial support refers to not supporting `.setDragImage`

internationalization.title: Internationalization API
internationalization.description: Locale-sensitive collation (string comparison), number formatting, and date and time formatting.

queryselector.title: querySelector/querySelectorAll
queryselector.description: Method of accessing DOM elements using CSS selectors

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in IE8 is due to being limited to [CSS 2.1 selectors](/#feat=css-sel2) and a small subset of [CSS 3 selectors](/#feat=css-sel3) (see notes there). Additionally, it will have trouble with selectors including unrecognized tags (for example HTML5 ones).

getelementsbyclassname.title: getElementsByClassName
getelementsbyclassname.description: Method of accessing DOM elements by class name

forms.title: HTML5 form features
forms.description: Expanded form options, including things like date pickers, sliders, validation, placeholders and multiple file uploads. Previously known as "Web forms 2.0".

links.title: HTML5 inputs and attribute support page
Cross-browser JS implementation (based on original spec)

html5semantic.title: New semantic elements
html5semantic.description: HTML5 offers some new elements, primarily for semantic purposes. The elements include: section, article, aside, header, footer, nav, figure, figcaption, time, mark, main.
html5semantic.notes: Partial support refers to missing the default styling. This is easily taken care of by using display:block for all new elements (except time and mark, these should be display:inline anyway).

notes_by_num.1: Does not include support for the <main> element

offline-apps.title: Offline web applications
offline-apps.description: Method of defining web page files to be cached using a cache manifest file, allowing them to work offline on subsequent visits to the page

webworkers.title: Web Workers
webworkers.description: Method of running scripts in the background, isolated from the web page

fontface.title: @font-face Web fonts
fontface.description: Method of displaying fonts downloaded from websites
fontface.notes: Not supported by IE Mobile 9 and below.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support refers to only supporting EOT fonts.
notes_by_num.2: Partial support refers to only supporting SVG fonts.

eot.title: EOT - Embedded OpenType fonts
eot.description: Type of font that can be derived from a regular font, allowing small files and legal use of high-quality fonts. Usage is restricted by the file being tied to the website
eot.notes: Proposal by Microsoft, being considered for W3C standardization.

woff.title: WOFF - Web Open Font Format
woff.description: Compressed TrueType/OpenType font that contains information about the font's source.

notes_by_num.1: Reported to be supported in some modified versions of the Android 4.0 browser.

multibackgrounds.title: CSS3 Multiple backgrounds
multibackgrounds.description: Method of using multiple images as a background

border-image.title: CSS3 Border images
border-image.description: Method of using images for borders
border-image.notes: Note that both the `border-style` and `border-width` must be specified (not set to `none` or 0) for border-images to work according to spec, though older implementations may not have this requirement. Partial support refers to supporting the shorthand syntax, but not the individual properties (border-image-source, border-image-slice, etc).

background-img-opts.title: CSS3 Background-image options
background-img-opts.description: New properties to affect background images, including background-clip, background-origin and background-size
background-img-opts.notes: Safari also supports the unofficial `-webkit-background-clip: text` (only with prefix)

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in Opera Mini refers to not supporting background sizing or background attachments. However Opera Mini 7.5 supports background sizing (including cover and contain values).
notes_by_num.2: Partial support in Safari 6 refers to not supporting background sizing offset from edges syntax.
notes_by_num.3: Does not support `background-size` values in the `background` shorthand

css-table.title: CSS Table display
css-table.description: Method of displaying elements as tables, rows, and cells

css-gencontent.title: CSS Generated content for pseudo-elements
css-gencontent.description: Method of displaying text or images before or after the given element's contents using the ::before and ::after pseudo-elements. All browsers with support also support the `attr()` notation in the `content` property.
css-gencontent.notes: For content to appear in pseudo-elements, the `content` property must be set (but may be an empty string).

notes_by_num.1: IE8 only supports the single-colon CSS 2.1 syntax (i.e. :pseudo-class). It does not support the double-colon CSS3 syntax (i.e. ::pseudo-element).

css-fixed.title: CSS position:fixed
css-fixed.description: Method of keeping an element in a fixed location regardless of scroll position

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in older iOS Safari refers to [buggy behavior](http://remysharp.com/2012/05/24/issues-with-position-fixed-scrolling-on-ios/).
notes_by_num.2: Only works in Android 2.1 thru 2.3 by using the following meta tag: <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, user-scalable=no">.

beacon.title: Beacon API
beacon.description: Allows data to be sent asynchronously to a server with `navigator.sendBeacon`, even after a page was closed. Useful for posting analytics data the moment a user was finished using the page.

hashchange.title: Hashchange event
hashchange.description: Event triggered in JavaScript when the URL's hash has changed (for example: page.html#foo to page.html#bar)

css-sel2.title: CSS 2.1 selectors
css-sel2.description: Basic CSS selectors including: `*` (universal selector), `>` (child selector), `:first-child`, `:link`, `:visited`, `:active`, `:hover`, `:focus`, `:lang()`, `+` (adjacent sibling selector), `[attr]`, `[attr="val"]`, `[attr~="val"]`, `[attr|="bar"]`, `.foo` (class selector), `#foo` (id selector)
css-sel2.notes: Support for `:visited` styling [varies across browsers](http://sixrevisions.com/css/visited-pseudo-class-strange/) due to security concerns.

css-sel3.title: CSS3 selectors
css-sel3.description: Advanced element selection using selectors including: `[foo^="bar"]`, `[foo$="bar"]`, `[foo*="bar"]`, `:root`, `:nth-child()`,  `:nth-last-child()`, `nth-of-type`, `nth-last-of-type()`, `:last-child`, `:first-of-type`, `:last-of-type`, `:only-child`, `:only-of-type`, `:empty`, `:target`, `:enabled`, `:disabled`, `:checked`, `:not()`, `~` (general sibling)

notes_by_num.1: IE7 and IE8 support only these CSS3 selectors: General siblings (`element1~element2`) and Attribute selectors `[attr^=val]`, `[attr$=val]`, and `[attr*=val]`

css-textshadow.title: CSS3 Text-shadow
css-textshadow.description: Method of applying one or more shadow or blur effects to text
css-textshadow.notes: Opera Mini ignores the blur-radius set, so no blur effect is visible. Text-shadow behavior can be somewhat emulated in older IE versions using the non-standard "dropshadow" or "glow" filters.

notes_by_num.1: IE 10+ supports a fourth length value for the shadow's "spread". This is not (yet) part of the specification.
notes_by_num.2: Partial support in Safari 3.* refers to not supporting multiple shadows.

css-boxshadow.title: CSS3 Box-shadow
css-boxshadow.description: Method of displaying an inner or outer shadow effect to elements
css-boxshadow.notes: Can be partially emulated in older IE versions using the non-standard "shadow" filter.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in Safari, iOS Safari and Android Browser refers to missing "inset", blur radius value, and multiple shadow support.

css3-colors.title: CSS3 Colors
css3-colors.description: Method of describing colors using Hue, Saturation and Lightness (hsl()) rather than just RGB, as well as allowing alpha-transparency with rgba() and hsla().

css3-boxsizing.title: CSS3 Box-sizing
css3-boxsizing.description: Method of specifying whether or not an element's borders and padding should be included in size units
css3-boxsizing.notes: Firefox currently also supports the `padding-box` in addition to `content-box` and `border-box`, though this value has been removed from the specification.

css-mediaqueries.title: CSS3 Media Queries
css-mediaqueries.description: Method of applying styles based on media information. Includes things like page and device dimensions

notes_by_num.1: Does not support nested media queries
notes_by_num.2: Partial support refers to only acknowledging different media rules on page reload

multicolumn.title: CSS3 Multiple column layout
multicolumn.description: Method of flowing information in multiple columns
multicolumn.notes: Partial support refers to not supporting the `break-before`, `break-after`, `break-inside` properties. Webkit browsers do have equivalent support for the non-standard `-webkit-column-break-*` properties while Firefox supports `page-break-*` to accomplish the same result (but only the `auto` and `always` values).

border-radius.title: CSS3 Border-radius (rounded corners)
border-radius.description: Method of making the border corners round

notes_by_num.1: Safari 6.1 and earlier did not apply `border-radius` correctly to image borders: http://stackoverflow.com/q/17202128

transforms2d.title: CSS3 2D Transforms
transforms2d.description: Method of transforming an element including rotating, scaling, etc. Includes support for `transform` as well as `transform-origin` properties.
transforms2d.notes: The scale transform can be emulated in IE < 9 using Microsoft's "zoom" extension, others are (not easily) possible using the MS Matrix filter

use-strict.title: ECMAScript 5 Strict Mode
use-strict.description: Method of placing code in a "strict" operating context.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in older Safari refers to strict mode still accepting a lot of JS that should be considered invalid.

devicepixelratio.title: Window.devicePixelRatio
devicepixelratio.description: Read-only property that returns the ratio of the (vertical) size of one physical pixel on the current display device to the size of one CSS pixel.
devicepixelratio.notes: As the page is zoomed in the number of device pixels that one CSS pixel covers increases, and therefore the value of devicePixelRatio will also increase.

transforms3d.title: CSS3 3D Transforms
transforms3d.description: Method of transforming an element in the third dimension using the `transform` property. Includes support for the `perspective` property to set the perspective in z-space and the `backface-visibility` property to toggle display of the reverse side of a 3D-transformed element.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in IE refers to not supporting [the transform-style: preserve-3d property](http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ie/hh673529%28v=vs.85%29.aspx#the_ms_transform_style_property). This prevents nesting 3D transformed elements.

sharedworkers.title: Shared Web Workers
sharedworkers.description: Method of allowing multiple scripts to communicate with a single web worker.

css-hyphens.title: CSS Hyphenation
css-hyphens.description: Method of controlling when words at the end of lines should be hyphenated using the "hyphens" property.
css-hyphens.notes: Chrome and Android 4.0 Browser support "-webkit-hyphens: none", but not the "auto" property. It is [advisable to set the @lang attribute](http://blog.adrianroselli.com/2015/01/on-use-of-lang-attribute.html) on the HTML element to enable hyphenation support and improve accessibility.

css-transitions.title: CSS3 Transitions
css-transitions.description: Simple method of animating certain properties of an element, with ability to define property, duration, delay and timing function.

links.title: Animation of property types support in Opera

css-transitions.notes: Support listed is for `transition` properties as well as the `transitionend` event. The prefixed name in WebKit browsers is `webkitTransitionEnd`

font-feature.title: CSS font-feature-settings
font-feature.description: Method of applying advanced typographic and language-specific font features to supported OpenType fonts.

links.title: Syntax for OpenType features in CSS (Adobe Typekit Help)

font-feature.notes: Whenever possible, font-variant shorthand property or an associated longhand property, font-variant-ligatures, font-variant-caps, font-variant-east-asian, font-variant-alternates, font-variant-numeric or font-variant-position should be used. This property is a low-level feature designed to handle special cases where no other way to enable or access an OpenType font feature exists. In particular, this CSS property shouldn't be used to enable small caps.

notes_by_num.1: From Gecko 2.0 (Firefox 4.0) to Gecko 14.0 (Firefox 14.0) included, Gecko supported an older syntax, slightly different from the modern one: http://hacks.mozilla.org/2010/11/firefox-4-font-feature-support/
notes_by_num.2: Partial support in older Chrome versions refers to lacking support in Mac OS X.

css-animation.title: CSS Animation
css-animation.description: Complex method of animating certain properties of an element

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in Android browser refers to buggy behavior in different scenarios.

css-gradients.title: CSS Gradients
css-gradients.description: Method of defining a linear or radial color gradient as a CSS image.

links.title: Tool to emulate support in IE

css-gradients.notes:
Syntax used by browsers with prefixed support may be incompatible with that for proper support.

Support can be somewhat emulated in older IE versions using the non-standard "gradient" filter. 

Firefox 10+, Opera 11.6+, Chrome 26+ and IE10+ also support the new "to (side)" syntax.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in Opera 11.10 and 11.50 also refers to only having support for linear gradients.

css-canvas.title: CSS Canvas Drawings
css-canvas.description: Method of using HTML5 Canvas as a background image. Not currently part of any specification.
css-canvas.notes: A similar effect can be achieved in Firefox 4+ using the -moz-element() background property

css-reflections.title: CSS Reflections
css-reflections.description: Method of displaying a reflection of an element

links.title: Microsoft Edge feature request on UserVoice

css-reflections.notes: Similar effect can be achieved in Firefox 4+ using the -moz-element() background property

css-masks.title: CSS Masks
css-masks.description: Method of displaying part of an element, using a selected image as a mask

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in WebKit/Blink browsers refers to supporting the mask-image and mask-box-image properties, but lacking support for other parts of the spec.
notes_by_num.2: Partial support in Firefox refers to only support for inline SVG mask elements i.e. mask: url(#foo).

console-basic.title: Basic console logging functions
console-basic.description: Method of outputting data to the browser's console, intended for development purposes.
console-basic.notes: The basic functions that this information refers to include `console.log`, `console.info`, `console.warn`, `console.error`.

notes_by_num.1: Only supports console functions when developer tools are open, otherwise the `console` object is undefined and any calls will throw errors.
notes_by_num.2: Allows `console` functions to be used without throwing errors, but does not appear to output the data anywhere.
notes_by_num.3: Log output on iOS 6+ Safari can only be seen by connecting to a Mac and using the [Safari debugger](https://developer.apple.com/safari/tools/).
notes_by_num.4: Log output on older Android browsers can be retrieved via Android's `logcat` command or using Chrome Developer Tools in Android 4.4+/Chrome for Android [see details](http://developer.android.com/guide/webapps/debugging.html)
notes_by_num.5: Log output on Firefox for Android can be [accessed using WebIDE](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Tools/Remote_Debugging/Debugging_Firefox_for_Android_with_WebIDE)

svg.title: SVG (basic support)
svg.description: Method of displaying basic Vector Graphics features using the embed or object elements. Refers to the SVG 1.1 spec.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in Android 3 & 4 refers to not supporting masking.
notes_by_num.2: IE9-11 desktop & mobile don't properly scale SVG files.  [Adding height, width, viewBox, and CSS rules](http://codepen.io/tomByrer/pen/qEBbzw?editors=110) seem to be the best workaround.

svg-css.title: SVG in CSS backgrounds
svg-css.description: Method of using SVG images as CSS backgrounds

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in iOS Safari and older Safari versions refers to failing to support tiling or the background-position property.
notes_by_num.2: Partial support in older Firefox and Opera Mini/Mobile refers to SVG images being blurry when scaled.

svg-smil.title: SVG SMIL animation
svg-smil.description: Method of using animation elements to animate SVG images

links.title: JS library to support SMIL in SVG
Polyfill for SMIL animate events on SVG

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in older Safari versions refers to not working in HTML files or CSS background images.
notes_by_num.2: As of Chrome 45 SMIL is deprecated and usage will result in a warning in the console. Support is expected to be dropped in some future version.

svg-fonts.title: SVG fonts
svg-fonts.description: Method of using fonts defined as SVG shapes. Considered among a number of browser vendors as a deprecated feature with support being removed.

links.title: Blog post on usage for iPad

notes_by_num.1: Chrome 38 and newer support SVG fonts only on Windows Vista and XP.
notes_by_num.2: Supported in Opera Mini in SVG images only, not in HTML.

svg-filters.title: SVG filters
svg-filters.description: Method of using photoshop-like effects on SVG objects including blurring and color manipulation.

svg-html.title: SVG effects for HTML
svg-html.description: Method of using SVG transforms, filters, etc on HTML elements using either CSS or the foreignObject element
svg-html.notes: Partial support refers to lack of filter support or buggy result from effects. A [CSS Filter Effects](http://www.w3.org/TR/filter-effects/) specification is in the works that would replace this method.

svg-html5.title: Inline SVG in HTML5
svg-html5.description: Method of using SVG tags directly in HTML documents. Requires HTML5 parser.

notes_by_num.1: Does not support CSS transforms on SVG elements (transform attribute can be used instead)

canvas.title: Canvas (basic support)
canvas.description: Method of generating fast, dynamic graphics using JavaScript.
canvas.notes:
For screen readers, IE, Chrome & Firefox support the [accessible canvas element sub-DOM](http://www.paciellogroup.com/blog/2012/06/html5-canvas-accessibility-in-firefox-13/).
Firefox & Chrome also support the drawfocus ring.

notes_by_num.1: Does not support `toDataURL()`
notes_by_num.2: Opera Mini supports the canvas element, but is unable to play animations or run other more complex applications.

canvas-text.title: Text API for Canvas
canvas-text.description: Method of displaying text on Canvas elements

namevalue-storage.title: Web Storage - name/value pairs
namevalue-storage.description: Method of storing data locally like cookies, but for larger amounts of data (sessionStorage and localStorage, used to fall under HTML5).

sql-storage.title: Web SQL Database
sql-storage.description: Method of storing data client-side, allows Sqlite database queries for access and manipulation
sql-storage.notes: The Web SQL Database specification is no longer being maintained and support may be dropped in future versions.

indexeddb.title: IndexedDB
indexeddb.description: Method of storing data client-side, allows indexed database queries.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in IE 10 & 11 refers to a number of subfeatures [not being supported](http://codepen.io/cemerick/pen/Itymi).
notes_by_num.2: Partial support in iOS 8 & 9 refers to [seriously buggy behavior](http://www.raymondcamden.com/2014/9/25/IndexedDB-on-iOS-8--Broken-Bad).

online-status.title: Online/offline status
online-status.description: Events to indicate when the user's connected (`online` and `offline` events) and the `navigator.onLine` property to see current status.
online-status.notes:
"online" does not always mean connection to the internet, it can also just mean connection to some network.

Early versions of Chrome and Safari always reported "true" for `navigator.onLine`

notes_by_num.0: Safari 7.0 supports only the event listener on `window`, and not on `document.body`
notes_by_num.1: Seems to support `navigator.onLine` but not `online`/`offline` events.
notes_by_num.2: IE8 only supports the `online`/`offline` events on `document.body`, rather than `window`.
notes_by_num.3: Desktop Firefox responds to the status of its "Work Offline" mode. If not in that mode, `navigator.onLine` is always `true`, regardless of the actual network connectivity status. [See bug](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=654579) for details.

eventsource.title: Server-sent events
eventsource.description: Method of continuously sending data from a server to the browser, rather than repeatedly requesting it (EventSource interface, used to fall under HTML5)

x-doc-messaging.title: Cross-document messaging
x-doc-messaging.description: Method of sending information from a page on one domain to a page on a different one (using postMessage)

notes_by_num.1: Partial support refers to only working in frames/iframes (not other tabs/windows). Also, objects cannot be sent using postMessage.
notes_by_num.2: Partial support refers to [limitations in certain conditions](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/16226924/is-cross-origin-postmessage-broken-in-ie10).

sni.title: Server Name Indication
sni.description: An extension to the TLS computer networking protocol by which a client indicates which hostname it is attempting to connect to at the start of the handshaking process.

notes_by_num.1: Only supported on Windows Vista or above (not Windows XP)

datauri.title: Data URIs
datauri.description: Method of embedding images and other files in webpages as a string of text, generally using base64 encoding.

notes_by_num.1: Support is limited to images and linked resources like CSS files, not HTML or JS files. Max URI length is 32KB.
notes_by_num.2: Support is limited to images and linked resources like CSS or JS, not HTML files. Maximum size limit is 4GB.

wav.title: Wav audio format
wav.description: Waveform Audio File Format, aka WAV or WAVE, a typically uncompressed audio format.
wav.notes: Support refers to use using the `audio` element, not other conditions.

mathml.title: MathML
mathml.description: Special tags that allow mathematical formulas and notations to be written on web pages.
mathml.notes: Opera's support is limited to a CSS profile of MathML. Support was added in Chrome 24, but removed afterwards due to instability.

notes_by_num.1: Before version 4, Firefox only supports the XHTML notation

css-featurequeries.title: CSS Feature Queries
css-featurequeries.description: CSS Feature Queries allow authors to condition rules based on whether particular property declarations are supported in CSS using the @supports at rule.

xhtml.title: XHTML served as application/xhtml+xml
xhtml.description: A strict form of HTML, and allows embedding of other XML languages
xhtml.notes: The XHTML syntax is very close to HTML, and thus is almost always ([incorrectly](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/XHTML#MIME_type_versus_DOCTYPE)) served as text/html on the web.

xhtmlsmil.title: XHTML+SMIL animation
xhtmlsmil.description: Method of using SMIL animation in web pages
xhtmlsmil.notes: Internet Explorer supports the W3C proposal HTML+TIME, which is largely the same as XHTML+SMIL

wai-aria.title: WAI-ARIA Accessibility features
wai-aria.description: Method of providing ways for people with disabilities to use dynamic web content and web applications.
wai-aria.notes: Support for ARIA is rather complex and currently is not fully supported in any browser. For detailed information on partial support see the [ARIA 1.0 Implementation Report](http://www.w3.org/WAI/ARIA/1.0/CR/implementation-report)

geolocation.title: Geolocation
geolocation.description: Method of informing a website of the user's geographical location

flexbox.title: Flexible Box Layout Module
flexbox.description: Method of positioning elements in horizontal or vertical stacks. Support includes the support for the all properties prefixed with `flex` as well as `display: flex`, `display: inline-flex`, `align-content`, `align-items`, `align-self`, `justify-content` and `order`.

links.title: Article on using the latest spec
Examples on how to solve common layout problems with flexbox

flexbox.notes: Most partial support refers to supporting an [older version](http://www.w3.org/TR/2009/WD-css3-flexbox-20090723/) of the specification or an [older syntax](http://www.w3.org/TR/2012/WD-css3-flexbox-20120322/).

notes_by_num.1: Only supports the [old flexbox](http://www.w3.org/TR/2009/WD-css3-flexbox-20090723) specification and does not support wrapping.
notes_by_num.2: Only supports the [2012 syntax](http://www.w3.org/TR/2012/WD-css3-flexbox-20120322/)
notes_by_num.3: Does not support flex-wrap or flex-flow properties

webgl.title: WebGL - 3D Canvas graphics
webgl.description: Method of generating dynamic 3D graphics using JavaScript, accelerated through hardware
webgl.notes:
Support listed as "partial" refers to the fact that not all users with these browsers have WebGL access. This is due to the additional requirement for users to have [up to date video drivers](http://www.khronos.org/webgl/wiki/BlacklistsAndWhitelists). This problem was [solved in Chrome on Windows](http://blog.chromium.org/2012/02/gpu-accelerating-2d-canvas-and-enabling.html) as of version 18.

Note that WebGL is part of the [Khronos Group](http://www.khronos.org/webgl/), not the W3C.

notes_by_num.1: WebGL context is accessed from "experimental-webgl" rather than "webgl"

fileapi.title: File API
fileapi.description: Method of manipulating file objects in web applications client-side, as well as programmatically selecting them and accessing their data.

notes_by_num.1: Does not have `FileReader` support.
notes_by_num.2: Does not support the `File` constructor

shadowdom.title: Shadow DOM
shadowdom.description: Method of establishing and maintaining functional boundaries between DOM trees and how these trees interact with each other within a document, thus enabling better functional encapsulation within the DOM.

notes_by_num.1: Supported in Firefox behind the `dom.webcomponents.enabled` flag.

websockets.title: Web Sockets
websockets.description: Bidirectional communication technology for web apps
websockets.notes: Reported to be supported in some Android 4.x browsers, including Sony Xperia S, Sony TX and HTC.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support refers to the websockets implementation using an older version of the protocol and/or the implementation being disabled by default (due to security issues with the older protocol).
notes_by_num.2: Partial support refers to lacking support for binary data.

hidden.title: hidden attribute
hidden.description: The `hidden` attribute may be applied to any element, and effectively hides elements similar to `display: none` in CSS.
hidden.notes: The hidden state can be easily overridden with a CSS `display` property set to anything other than `none`.

script-async.title: async attribute for external scripts
script-async.description: The boolean async attribute on script elements allows the external JavaScript file to run when it's available, without delaying page load first.

notes_by_num.1: Using script.async = false; to maintain execution order for dynamically-added scripts isn't supported in Safari 5.0

mediasource.title: Media Source Extensions
mediasource.description: API allowing media data to be accessed from HTML `video` and `audio` elements.

notes_by_num.1: Requires the `media.mediasource.enabled` flag to be enabled
notes_by_num.2: Partial support in IE11 refers to only working in Windows 8+

cors.title: Cross-Origin Resource Sharing
cors.description: Method of performing XMLHttpRequests across domains

notes_by_num.1: Does not support CORS for images in `<canvas>`
notes_by_num.2: Supported somewhat in IE8 and IE9 using the XDomainRequest object (but has [limitations]( http://blogs.msdn.com/b/ieinternals/archive/2010/05/13/xdomainrequest-restrictions-limitations-and-workarounds.aspx))
notes_by_num.3: Does not support CORS for `<video>` in `<canvas>`: https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=135379

css-backdrop-filter.title: CSS Backdrop Filter
css-backdrop-filter.description: Method of applying filter effects (like blur, grayscale or hue) to content/elements below the target element.

calc.title: calc() as CSS unit value
calc.description: Method of allowing calculated values for length units, i.e. `width: calc(100% - 3em)`
calc.notes:
Support can be somewhat emulated in older versions of IE using the non-standard `expression()` syntax.

Due to the way browsers handle [sub-pixel rounding](http://ejohn.org/blog/sub-pixel-problems-in-css/) differently, layouts using `calc()` expressions may have unexpected results.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in Android Browser 4.4 refers to the browser lacking the ability to multiply and divide values.
notes_by_num.2: Partial support in IE9 refers to the browser crashing when used as a `background-position` value.

dom-range.title: Document Object Model Range
dom-range.description: A contiguous range of content in a Document, DocumentFragment or Attr

links.title: "Rangy" Range library with old IE support

ruby.title: Ruby annotation
ruby.description: Method of adding pronunciation or other annotations using ruby elements (primarily used in East Asian typography).
ruby.notes: Browsers without native support can still simulate support using CSS. Partial support refers to only supporting basic ruby, may still be missing writing-mode, Complex ruby and CSS3 Ruby.

notes_by_num.1: IE9+ supports [properties](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/hh772055%28v=vs.85%29.aspx) of an older version of the CSS Ruby specification.

css-opacity.title: CSS3 Opacity
css-opacity.description: Method of setting the transparency level of an element
css-opacity.notes: Transparency for elements in IE8 and older can be achieved using the proprietary "filter" property and does not work well with PNG images using alpha transparency.

form-validation.title: Form validation
form-validation.description: Method of setting required fields and field types without requiring JavaScript. This includes preventing forms from being submitted when appropriate, the `checkValidity()` method as well as support for the `:invalid`, `:valid`, and `:required` CSS pseudo-classes.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support refers to lack of notice when form with required fields is attempted to be submitted.
notes_by_num.2: Partial support in IE10 mobile refers to lack of warning when blocking submission.
notes_by_num.3: Partial support in Opera Mini refers to only supporting the CSS pseudo classes.

history.title: Session history management
history.description: Method of manipulating the user's browser's session history in JavaScript using `history.pushState`, `history.replaceState` and the `popstate` event.
history.notes: Older iOS versions and Android 4.0.4 claim support, but implementation is too buggy to be useful.

json.title: JSON parsing
json.description: Method of converting JavaScript objects to JSON strings and JSON back to objects using JSON.stringify() and JSON.parse()

notes_by_num.1: Requires document to be in IE8+ [standards mode](http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/cc288325%28VS.85%29.aspx) to work in IE8.

classlist.title: classList (DOMTokenList)
classlist.description: Method of easily manipulating classes on elements, using the DOMTokenList object.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support refers to not working on SVG elements.
notes_by_num.2: Partial support refers to not supporting the second parameter for the `toggle` method

text-overflow.title: CSS3 Text-overflow
text-overflow.description: Append ellipsis when text overflows its containing element

webm.title: WebM video format
webm.description: Multimedia format designed to provide a royalty-free, high-quality open video compression format for use with HTML5 video. WebM supports the video codec VP8 and VP9.

links.title: Info on supporting WebM in Safari

webm.notes: Will work in IE9+ and Safari/MacOSX provided the user has the WebM codecs installed. Partial support indicates that at least one codec is supported but not all.

mpeg4.title: MPEG-4/H.264 video format

links.title: Firefox extension allowing support in Win7

mpeg4.notes:
Firefox supports H.264 on Windows 7 and later since version 21. Firefox supports H.264 on Linux since version 26 if the appropriate gstreamer plug-ins are installed.

Partial support for older Firefox versions refers to the lack of support in OS X & some non-Android Linux platforms.

notes_by_num.1: The Android 2.3 browser requires [specific handling](http://www.broken-links.com/2010/07/08/making-html5-video-work-on-android-phones/) to play videos.
notes_by_num.2: Partial supports refers to the lack of hardware acceleration.

wordwrap.title: CSS3 Overflow-wrap
wordwrap.description: Allows lines to be broken within words if an otherwise unbreakable string is too long to fit. Currently mostly supported using the `word-wrap` property.

links.title: Microsoft Edge feature request on UserVoice

wordwrap.notes: Partial support refers to requiring the legacy name "word-wrap" (rather than "overflow-wrap") to work.

pointerlock.title: PointerLock API
pointerlock.description: API that provides access to raw mouse movement data. This is done by ignoring boundaries resulting from screen edges where the cursor can't go beyond, providing proper control for first person or real time strategy games.

object-fit.title: CSS3 object-fit/object-position
object-fit.description: Method of specifying how an object (image or video) should fit inside its box. object-fit options include "contain" (fit according to aspect ratio), "fill" (stretches object to fill) and "cover" (overflows box but maintains ratio), where object-position allows the object to be repositioned like background-image does.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in Safari refers to support for `object-fit` but not `object-position`.

xhr2.title: XMLHttpRequest advanced features
xhr2.description: Adds more functionality to XHR (aka AJAX) requests like file uploads, transfer progress information and the ability to send form data. Previously known as [XMLHttpRequest Level 2](http://www.w3.org/TR/2012/WD-XMLHttpRequest-20120117/), these features now appear simply in the XMLHttpRequest spec.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support refers to not supporting `json` as `responseType`
notes_by_num.2: Partial support refers to not supporting `.timeout` and `.ontimeout`
notes_by_num.3: Partial support refers to not supporting `blob` as `responseType`

minmaxwh.title: CSS min/max-width/height
minmaxwh.description: Method of setting a minimum or maximum width or height to an element.

notes_by_num.1: IE7 does not support `inherit` as a value on any of these properties.
notes_by_num.2: IE8 has some bugs with `max-width`/`height` combined with `overflow: auto`/`scroll`.

details.title: Details & Summary elements
details.description: The <details> element generates a simple no-JavaScript widget to show/hide element contents, optionally by clicking on its child <summary> element.

text-stroke.title: CSS text-stroke
text-stroke.description: Method of declaring the outline (stroke) width and color for text.
text-stroke.notes: Does not yet appear in any W3C specification. Was briefly included in a spec as the "text-outline" property, but this was removed.

inline-block.title: CSS inline-block
inline-block.description: Method of displaying an element as a block while flowing it with text.

notes_by_num.1: Only supported in IE6 and IE7 on elements with a display of "inline" by default. [Alternative properties](http://blog.mozilla.com/webdev/2009/02/20/cross-browser-inline-block/) are available to provide complete cross-browser support.

notifications.title: Web Notifications
notifications.description: Method of alerting the user outside of a web page by displaying notifications (that do not require interaction by the user).

stream.title: getUserMedia/Stream API
stream.description: Method of accessing external device data (such as a webcam video stream). Formerly this was envisioned as the <device> element.

links.title: Media Capture functionality in Microsoft Edge

notes_by_num.1: Blink-based (and some other) browsers support an older version of the spec that does not use `srcObject`. [See Chromium issue 387740](https://code.google.com/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=387740). Instead you need to convert a `MediaStream` object using `UR

svg-img.title: SVG in HTML img element
svg-img.description: Method of displaying SVG images in HTML using .

notes_by_num.1: Partial support refers to not supporting embedded images (data URIs) inside the SVG.

datalist.title: Datalist element
datalist.description: Method of setting a list of options for a user to select in a text field, while leaving the ability to enter a custom value.
datalist.notes: While most commonly used on text fields, datalists can also be used on other input types. IE11 supports the element on `range` fields. Chrome and Opera also support datalists to suggest given values on `range`, `color` and date/time fields.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support refers to [a bug](https://code.google.com/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=375637) where long lists of items are unscrollable resulting in unselectable options.
notes_by_num.2: Partial support in IE refers to [significantly buggy behavior](http://playground.onereason.eu/2013/04/ie10s-lousy-support-for-datalists/) (IE11+ does send the input and change events upon selection).
notes_by_num.3: Partial support refers to no support for datalists on non-text fields (e.g. number, [range](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=841942), [color](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=960984)).

dataset.title: dataset & data-* attributes
dataset.description: Method of applying and accessing custom data to elements.
dataset.notes:
Partial support refers to being able to use `data-*` attributes and access them using `getAttribute`. 

"Supported" refers to accessing the values using the `dataset` property. Current spec only refers to support on HTML elements, only some browsers also have support for SVG/MathML elements.

notes_by_num.1: While the HTML spec doesn't require it, these browsers also support `dataset` and `data-*` attributes on SVG elements, in compliance with [current plans for SVG2](http://www.w3.org/2015/01/15-svg-minutes.html#item03)

css-grid.title: CSS Grid Layout
css-grid.description: Method of using a grid concept to lay out content, providing a mechanism for authors to divide available space for lay out into columns and rows using a set of predictable sizing behaviors

notes_by_num.1: Enabled in Chrome through the "experimental Web Platform features" flag in chrome://flags
notes_by_num.2: Partial support in IE refers to supporting an [older version](http://www.w3.org/TR/2011/WD-css3-grid-layout-20110407/) of the specification.
notes_by_num.3: Enabled in Firefox through the `layout.css.grid.enabled ` flag

menu.title: Toolbar/context menu
menu.description: Method of defining a toolbar menu, a context menu or a list of (interactive) options using the <menu> element.

links.title: Microsoft Edge feature request on UserVoice

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in Firefox refers to being limited to context menus, not toolbar menus.

css-zoom.title: CSS zoom

links.title: Article explaining usage of zoom as the hack for fixing rendering bugs in IE6 and IE7.

css-zoom.notes: Originally implemented only in Internet Explorer. Although several other browsers support the property, using `transform: scale()` is the recommended solution to scale content.

notes_by_num.1: The `-ms-zoom` property is an extension to CSS, and can be used as a synonym for `zoom` in IE8 Standards mode.

rem.title: rem (root em) units
rem.description: Type of unit similar to `em`, but relative only to the root element, not any parent element. Thus compounding does not occur as it does with `em` units.

notes_by_num.1: IE 9 & IE 10 do not support `rem` units when used in the `font` shorthand property (the entire declaration is ignored) or when used on pseudo elements.

ttf.title: TTF/OTF - TrueType and OpenType font support
ttf.description: Support for the TrueType (.ttf) and OpenType (.otf) outline font formats in @font-face.

links.title: What is the status of TTF support in Internet Explorer?

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in IE9+ refers to the fonts only working [when set to be "installable"](http://blogs.msdn.com/b/ie/archive/2010/07/15/the-css-corner-better-web-typography-for-better-design.aspx). Support for this is tracked [here](https://status.modern.ie/crossdomainfontloading).

touch.title: Touch events
touch.description: Method of registering when, where and how the interface is touched, for devices with a touch screen. These DOM events are similar to mousedown, mousemove, etc.

links.title: Internet Explorer's gesture and touch implementation.
Touch polyfill for supporting touch events on Internet Explorer

touch.notes:
Internet Explorer implements Pointer Events specification which supports more input devices than Touch Events one.

There is a library on GitHub that is working toward bringing W3C touch events to IE 10 and 11: https://github.com/CamHenlin/TouchPolyfill 

Removed support in Firefox refers to desktop Firefox only.

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled in Firefox using the dom.w3c_touch_events.enabled flag (disabled by default for site compatibility reasons)
notes_by_num.2: Supported on IE11 Mobile for phones with "[Windows Phone 8.1 Update](http://blogs.msdn.com/b/ie/archive/2014/07/31/the-mobile-web-should-just-work-for-everyone.aspx)"

matchesselector.title: matches() DOM method
matchesselector.description: Method of testing whether or not a DOM element matches a given selector. Formerly known (and largely supported with prefix) as matchesSelector.

links.title: Microsoft Edge feature request on UserVoice

matchesselector.notes: Partial support refers to supporting the older specification's "matchesSelector" name rather than just "matches".

pointer-events.title: CSS pointer-events (for HTML)
pointer-events.description: This CSS property, when set to "none" allows elements to not receive hover/click events, instead the event will occur on anything behind it.
pointer-events.notes: Already part of the SVG specification, and all SVG-supporting browsers appear to support the property on SVG elements.

blobbuilder.title: Blob constructing
blobbuilder.description: Construct Blobs (binary large objects) either using the BlobBuilder API (deprecated) or the Blob constructor.
blobbuilder.notes: Partial support refers to only supporting the now deprecated BlobBuilder to create blobs.

filereader.title: FileReader API
filereader.description: Method of reading the contents of a File or Blob object into memory

notes_by_num.1: Does not support `readAsBinaryString`

filesystem.title: Filesystem & FileWriter API
filesystem.description: Method of reading and writing files to a sandboxed file system.
filesystem.notes: The File API: Directories and System specification is no longer being maintained and support may be dropped in future versions.

bloburls.title: Blob URLs
bloburls.description: Method of creating URL handles to the specified File or Blob object.

rellist.title: relList (DOMTokenList)
rellist.description: Method of easily manipulating rel attribute values on elements, using the DOMTokenList object (similar to classList).

typedarrays.title: Typed Arrays
typedarrays.description: JavaScript typed arrays provide a mechanism for accessing raw binary data much more efficiently.

notes_by_num.1: IE10 (and IE 10&11 mobile) does not support `Uint8ClampedArray`

deviceorientation.title: DeviceOrientation & DeviceMotion events
deviceorientation.description: API for detecting orientation and motion events from the device running the browser.
deviceorientation.notes: Partial support refers to the lack of compassneedscalibration event. Partial support also refers to the lack of devicemotion event support for Chrome 30- and Opera. Opera Mobile 14 lost the ondevicemotion event support. Firefox 3.6, 4 and 5 support the non-standard [MozOrientation](https://developer.mozilla.org/en/DOM/MozOrientation) event.

notes_by_num.1: `compassneedscalibration` supported in IE11 only for compatible devices with Windows 8.1+.

script-defer.title: defer attribute for external scripts
script-defer.description: The boolean defer attribute on script elements allows the external JavaScript file to run when the DOM is loaded, without delaying page load first.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in older IE refers to a buggy implementation (see issue).

nav-timing.title: Navigation Timing API
nav-timing.description: API for accessing timing information related to navigation and elements.
nav-timing.notes: Removed in iOS 8.1 due to poor performance.

audio-api.title: Web Audio API
audio-api.description: High-level JavaScript API for processing and synthesizing audio

links.title: Polyfill to support Web Audio API in Firefox
Additional browser compatibility tests for specific features
Polyfill to enable Web Audio API through Firefox Audio Data api or flash

audio-api.notes:
Firefox versions < 25 support an alternative, deprecated audio API.

Chrome support [went through some changes](http://updates.html5rocks.com/2014/07/Web-Audio-Changes-in-m36) as of version 36.

css-regions.title: CSS Regions
css-regions.description: Method of flowing content into multiple elements.

notes_by_num.1: Support is limited to using an iframe as a content source with the `-ms-flow-into: flow_name;` and `-ms-flow-from: flow_name;` syntax.

spellcheck-attribute.title: Spellcheck attribute
spellcheck-attribute.description: Attribute for `input`/`textarea` fields to enable/disable the browser's spellchecker.
spellcheck-attribute.notes:
The partial support in mobile browsers results from their OS generally having built-in spell checking instead of using the wavy underline to indicate misspelled words. `spellcheck="false"` does not seem to have any effect in these browsers.

Browsers have different behavior in how they deal with spellchecking in combination with the the `lang` attribute. Generally spelling is based on the browser's language, not the language of the document.

fullscreen.title: Full Screen API
fullscreen.description: API for allowing content (like a video or canvas element) to take up the entire screen.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support refers to supporting an earlier draft of the spec.
notes_by_num.2: Partial support refers to not supporting `::backdrop`, and supporting the old `:full-screen` syntax rather than the standard `:fullscreen`.

css-exclusions.title: CSS Exclusions Level 1
css-exclusions.description: Exclusions defines how inline content flows around elements. It extends the content wrapping ability of floats to any block-level element.

requestanimationframe.title: requestAnimationFrame
requestanimationframe.description: API allowing a more efficient way of running script-based animation, compared to traditional methods using timeouts. Also covers support for `cancelAnimationFrame`

notes_by_num.1: Partial support refers to lacking `cancelAnimationFrame` support.
notes_by_num.2: Supports `webkitCancelRequestAnimationFrame` rather than `webkitCancelAnimationFrame.

input-range.title: Range input type
input-range.description: Form field type that allows the user to select a value using a slider widget.
input-range.notes: Currently all Android browsers with partial support hide the slider input field by default. However, the element [can be styled](http://tiffanybbrown.com/2012/02/07/input-typerange-and-androids-stock-browser/) to be made visible and usable.

matchmedia.title: matchMedia
matchmedia.description: API for finding out whether or not a media query applies to the document.

input-datetime.title: Date and time input types
input-datetime.description: Form field widget to easily allow users to enter a date or a time, generally by using a calendar/time input widget.
input-datetime.notes:
Older versions of Safari provide date-formatted text fields, but no real calendar widget.

Chrome and Opera also support the `datetime-local` type for both date and time, but not the `datetime` one.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in Microsoft Edge refers to supporting `date`, `week`, and `month` input types and not `time`, `datetime`, and `datetime-local`.
notes_by_num.2: Partial support in iOS Safari refers to not supporting `min`, `max` or `step` attributes
notes_by_num.3: Some modified versions of the Android 4.x browser do have support for date/time fields.

input-color.title: Color input type
input-color.description: Form field allowing the user to select a color.

links.title: Microsoft Edge feature request on UserVoice

notes_by_num.1: UI widget does not include increment/decrement buttons.
notes_by_num.2: UI widget does not take the "step", "min" or "max" attributes into account.
notes_by_num.3: Firefox doesn't support [autocomplete content via datalist](http://codepen.io/graste/pen/bNoVKW) elements.

getboundingclientrect.title: Element.getBoundingClientRect()
getboundingclientrect.description: Method to get the size and position of an element's bounding box, relative to the viewport.

notes_by_num.1: The returned object lacks `width` and `height` properties.
notes_by_num.2: Returns incorrect values for elements which have had CSS `transform`s applied to them.
notes_by_num.3: The returned object cannot have new properties added to it; it's not extensible.
notes_by_num.4: Existing properties of the returned object are immutable.

iframe-sandbox.title: sandbox attribute for iframes
iframe-sandbox.description: Method of running external site pages with reduced privileges (e.g. no JavaScript) in iframes.

css-counters.title: CSS Counters
css-counters.description: Method of controlling number values in generated content, using the `counter-reset` and `counter-increment` properties.

css-resize.title: CSS resize property
css-resize.description: Method of allowing an element to be resized by the user, with options to limit to a given direction.

links.title: Microsoft Edge feature request on UserVoice

notes_by_num.1: Presto-based Opera 12.10+ currently only supports the resize property for textarea elements.

input-placeholder.title: input placeholder attribute
input-placeholder.description: Method of setting placeholder text for text-like input fields, to suggest the expected inserted information.

links.title: Issue 24626: Placeholder text for an input type=

notes_by_num.1: Partial support refers to lacking placeholder support on textarea elements.

spdy.title: SPDY protocol
spdy.description: Networking protocol for low-latency transport of content over the web. Superseded by HTTP version 2.
spdy.notes:
See also support for [HTTP2](http://caniuse.com/#feat=http2), successor of SPDY.

Chrome will be removing support in 2016 (in favor of HTTP2), other browsers likely to follow.

css-repeating-gradients.title: CSS Repeating Gradients
css-repeating-gradients.description: Method of defining a repeating linear or radial color gradient as a CSS image.
css-repeating-gradients.notes: Firefox 10+, Chrome 26+ and Opera 11.6+ also support the new "to (side)" syntax.

css-filters.title: CSS Filter Effects
css-filters.description: Method of applying filter effects (like blur, grayscale, brightness, contrast and hue) to elements, previously only possible by using SVG.
css-filters.notes: Note that this property is significantly different from and incompatible with Microsoft's [older "filter" property](http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ie/ms530752%28v=vs.85%29.aspx).

notes_by_num.1: Supported in Firefox under the `layout.css.filters.enabled` flag.
notes_by_num.2: Supported in MS Edge under the "Enable CSS filter property" flag. Supports filter functions, but not the `url` function.
notes_by_num.3: Partial support in Firefox before version 34 [only implemented the url() function of the filter property](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/filter#Browser_compatibility)

getcomputedstyle.title: getComputedStyle
getcomputedstyle.description: API to get the current computed CSS styles applied to an element. This may be the current value applied by an animation or as set by a stylesheet.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support refers to requiring the second parameter to be included.
notes_by_num.2: Partial support refers to not supporting getComputedStyle on pseudo-elements.

mp3.title: MP3 audio format
mp3.notes: Support refers to use using the `audio` element, not other conditions.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in older Firefox refers to being limited to certain operating systems.

word-break.title: CSS3 word-break
word-break.description: Property to prevent or allow words to be broken over multiple lines between letters.
word-break.notes:
Partial support refers to supporting the `break-all` value, but not the `keep-all` value.

Chrome, Safari and other WebKit/Blink browsers also support the unofficial `break-word` value which is treated like `word-wrap: break-word`.

viewport-units.title: Viewport units: vw, vh, vmin, vmax
viewport-units.description: Length units representing 1% of the viewport size for viewport width (vw), height (vh), the smaller of the two (vmin), or the larger of the two (vmax).

links.title: Buggyfill - Polyfill that fixes buggy support
Microsoft Edge feature request on UserVoice

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in IE9 refers to supporting "vm" instead of "vmin".
notes_by_num.2: Partial support refers to not supporting the "vmax" unit.
notes_by_num.3: Partial support in iOS7 is due to buggy behavior of the "vh" unit (see [workaround](https://gist.github.com/pburtchaell/e702f441ba9b3f76f587)).

contentsecuritypolicy.title: Content Security Policy 1.0
contentsecuritypolicy.description: Mitigate cross-site scripting attacks by whitelisting allowed sources of script, style, and other resources.
contentsecuritypolicy.notes: The standard HTTP header is `Content-Security-Policy` which is used unless otherwise noted.

notes_by_num.1: Supported through the `X-Content-Security-Policy` header
notes_by_num.2: Supported through the `X-Webkit-CSP` header

pagevisibility.title: Page Visibility
pagevisibility.description: JavaScript API for determining whether a document is visible on the display

stricttransportsecurity.title: Strict Transport Security
stricttransportsecurity.description: Declare that a website is only accessible over a secure connection (HTTPS).

notes_by_num.1: IE 11 added support [in an update](http://blogs.windows.com/msedgedev/2015/06/09/http-strict-transport-security-comes-to-internet-explorer-11-on-windows-8-1-and-windows-7/) on June 9, 2015

style-scoped.title: Scoped CSS
style-scoped.description: Allows CSS rules to be scoped to part of the document, based on the position of the style element.

notes_by_num.1: Enabled in Chrome through the "experimental Web Platform features" flag in chrome://flags

svg-fragment.title: SVG fragment identifiers
svg-fragment.description: Method of displaying only a part of an SVG image by defining a view ID or view box dimensions as the file's fragment identifier.
